questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of the inactive phase of otosclerosis?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Features

Histological features

Active phase

Characterized by

  • Vascular proliferation
  • Excessive remodeling (Option B)
  • Increased osteoclast and osteoblast activity.

The bone becomes spongy in appearance due to fibroblasts and histiocytes in the stroma, leading to the term otospongiosis.

The new blood vessels are surrounded by a layer of new bone which stains blue on H and E stain hence known as the blue mantle of Manasse

Inactive phase

Marked by dense, hypercellular, sclerotic bone, with minimal remodeling

(Options A, C, D)

Mature foci show less vascularity and lay off more bone and more of fibrillar substance than cementum and are stained red.

questions.text: A patient with otosclerosis undergoes a stapedectomy, but the air-bone gap persists. The surgeon suspects a third window effect. In which type of otosclerosis does this occur?
questions.explanation:
Types

Features

Stapedial otosclerosis (Option C)

Causes fixation of stapes and conductive deafness is the most common variety.

Types include

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Biscuit type (Option D)
  • Circumferential
  • Obliterative

Cochlear otosclerosis

Involves a region of a round window or other areas in the otic capsule, and may cause sensorineural hearing loss probably due to the liberation of toxic materials into the inner ear fluid.

Histologic Otosclerosis (Option A)

asymptomatic and causes neither conductive nor sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with early-stage otosclerosis presents with progressive conductive hearing loss and a normal tympanic membrane. Which CT finding indicates the active phase of the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Dense sclerotic bone around the stapes footplate

options.label: B
options.text: Lucent (hypodense) foci in the otic capsule near the stapes footplate

options.label: C
options.text: Erosion of the cochlear capsule with hypodense areas

options.label: D
options.text: Normal bone density with no abnormalities

questions.correct_answer: B. Lucent (hypodense) foci in the otic capsule near the stapes footplate

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with progressive hearing loss in his left ear over the past few years. Audiometry shows hearing loss predominantly in lower frequencies, and otoscopic examination reveals a normal tympanic membrane. The patient denies experiencing tinnitus or vertigo. The patient’s hearing loss is mild and not significantly affecting his daily life. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Mechanism

Duration

Benefits

Sodium Fluoride (NaF) (Option D)

Stabilizes hearing thresholds and vestibular symptoms. Combined with calcium carbonate and vitamin D for enhanced effect.

At least 6 months

Delays worsening tinnitus

Reduces conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

Bisphosphonates (Option B)

Stabilizes hearing loss, reduces dizziness and tinnitus.

At least 6 months

Stabilizes hearing loss

Relieves vestibular symptoms

questions.text: A 6 year old boy presents with ear pain, and hearing loss for the past 2 days. He also has a recent history of the common cold. Otoscopy shows a retracted tympanic membrane with fluid. What is the most likely cause of his condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa

options.label: C
options.text: Biofilm formation in the middle ear

questions.text: A 4 year old girl presents with ear pain, fever, and a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, her tympanic membrane is red and bulging. What is the most likely route of infection for her condition?
questions.explanation:
ASOM Etiology

Common Predisposing Factors

Bacterial Causes
  • Frequent colds and upper respiratory tract infections.
  • Tonsil and adenoid infections.
  • Chronic nasal conditions like rhinitis and sinusitis.
  • Allergies involving the nasal passages.
  • Nasopharyngeal tumours or nasal packing for epistaxis (nosebleeds).
  • Cleft palate
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (30% of cases)
  • Haemophilus influenza (20%)
  • Moraxella catarrhalis (12%)
  • Occasionally, Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa also contribute.

questions.text: A 6 year old child presents with a history of mild hearing loss, difficulty following conversations, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. On examination, the tympanic membrane appears dull and retracted, with visible fluid levels behind it. Which of the following tuning fork test results is most likely to be observed in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the unaffected ear

options.label: B
options.text: Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the affected ear

options.label: C
options.text: Positive Rinne test and Weber test lateralized to the affected ear

options.label: D
options.text: Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the unaffected ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Negative Rinne test, Weber test lateralized to the affected ear
questions.explanation:
Category

Details

Symptoms
  • Hearing Loss: Conductive, mild to moderate (20-40 dB), gradual onset, may fluctuate; children may not complain, but parents may notice difficulties in hearing.
  • Delayed/Defective Speech
  • Mild Earaches
  • Fullness in Ear.

Signs

  • Tympanic Membrane Appearance: Dull, opaque, possibly yellow, grey, or bluish; absence of the usual light reflex.
  • Visible Fluid/Bubbles: Air-fluid levels or bubbles visible behind the eardrum.
  • Retracted Tympanic Membrane: Negative middle ear pressure causing eardrum retraction, with the malleus handle appearing shortened or horizontal.
  • Reduced Tympanic Membrane Mobility.

Test

Description

Rinne Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), bone conduction is better than air conduction (negative Rinne test).

Weber Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the sound is louder in the affected ear when the tuning fork is placed on the forehead.

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for a similar duration when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals plugged) in conductive hearing loss (SOM). (Bone conduction not impaired)

Schwabach's Test
  • In conductive hearing loss (SOM), the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner when placed on the mastoid bone (ear canals not plugged).

Pneumatic Otoscopy
  • Visualizes eardrum movement with air pressure changes; reduced/absent movement indicates fluid presence.

Impedance audiometry
  • Measures eardrum movement; typically shows a flat/dome-shaped curve with negative pressure, indicating reduced compliance.

Audiometry
  • Conductive hearing loss (20-40 dB).
  • Sometimes, associated sensorineural hearing loss (d/t fluid on the round window membrane.

X-ray/CT Scan of Temporal Bone
  • May show mastoid air cell clouding due to fluid

questions.text: Which of the following tympanometry curves corresponds to Serous Otitis Media?

A 5 year old child diagnosed with serous otitis media has persistent middle ear fluid despite medical treatment and even myringotomy and fluid aspiration. Which of the following is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Treatment

Details

Decongestants

Topical or systemic decongestants relieve eustachian tube oedema.

Antiallergic Measures

Use of antihistamines or steroids; allergen avoidance or desensitisation if possible.

Antibiotics

Useful for treating upper respiratory tract infections or unresolved acute suppurative otitis media. (Option C ruled out)

Middle Ear Aeration

Techniques include the Valsalva manoeuvre, politzerization, eustachian tube catheterization, insufflation, and chewing gum to open the tube.

Procedure

Details

Myringotomy and Aspiration of Fluid

An incision in the tympanic membrane to aspirate fluid; thick mucus may require saline or mucolytic agents like chymotrypsin solution.

Grommet Insertion

If fluid recurs after myringotomy and aspiration, a grommet is inserted for continued middle ear aeration; remains in place for weeks or months.

Tympanotomy or Cortical Mastoidectomy

Required for removing loculated thick fluid or other pathologies like cholesterol granuloma.

Surgical Treatment of Causative Factor

Procedures like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and/or maxillary antra washout may be needed, typically performed during myringotomy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with Congenital cholesteatoma. According to Levenson's criteria, which factor is NOT used to diagnose this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Intact pars flaccida and pars tensa

questions.correct_answer: C. Family history of Congenital Cholesteatoma
questions.explanation:
Classification of Cholesteatoma

Congenital Cholesteatoma

Acquired Cholesteatoma
  • Congenital cholesteatoma arises from embryonic epidermal cell rests.
  • It can occur in the middle ear, petrous apex, or cerebellopontine angle.
  • In the middle ear, it presents as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane.
  • It causes conductive hearing loss.
  • It may be discovered during routine exams or myringotomy.
  • It can spontaneously rupture, leading to ear discharge similar to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).
  • Diagnosed using Levenson's criteria:
    • Presence of a whitish mass behind a normal tympanic membrane; (Option A ruled out)
    • An intact pars flaccida and pars tensa; (Option B ruled out)
    • No previous history of ear discharge or perforation;
    • No prior ear surgeries; (Option D ruled out)
    • Ruling out conditions such as canal atresia, intramembranous cholesteatoma, or giant cholesteatoma.
    • A history of otitis media was not ruled out.

Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma

Occurs without a history of prior otitis media or a preexisting perforation. Its genesis is attributed to three main theories:

(a) Invagination of pars flaccida: Persistent negative pressure causes retraction and accumulation of keratin debris, leading to an expanding cholesteatoma.

(b) Basal cell hyperplasia: Proliferation of basal cells in the pars flaccida due to infections results in cholesteatoma formation and attic perforation.

(c) Squamous metaplasia: Normal attic epithelium transforms into keratinizing squamous epithelium due to subclinical infections.

Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma

Occurs with a preexisting perforation in the pars tensa, often a posterosuperior marginal or large central perforation. Its development is attributed to:

(a) Migration of squamous epithelium: Keratinizing squamous epithelium from the external ear or tympanic membrane migrates through the perforation into the middle ear.

(b) Metaplasia: Repeated infections cause the middle ear mucosa to transform into keratinizing squamous epithelium through the perforation.
